title: SPIKE: Experiment tooling
description:
TLDR: In growth engineering there seems to be a consensus to go
forward with the GLEX (GitLab experiment gem) implementation among
engineering team members. In order to meet product requirements, we
need to be able to measure financial and other KPIs for individual
namespaces, projects, and users by being able to merge data in CustomersDot,
Zuora, Salesforce, GitLab.com, and VersionsDot App databases. The recommended 
next step is to proceed with GLEX and add the ability to record some data into the
same backend tables, as is currently possible using EXMOD. We need to also improve the
tooling and standardize the charts.


## INVESTIGATION

In the growth team, we have the following ways to run experiments and
launch non-experiment features which enable data-based decisions.

1. Experimentation Module (EXMOD)
2. GLEX
3. Feature flag rollouts based on Flipper feature flags
4. Snowplow-based tracking for measuring user interactions
5. Data warehouse based analysis of gitlab.com, CustomersDot and other analysis
4. User surveys


I read through existing discussions and had sync surveys with
some growth engineers, product managers, and designers.

## BUY OPTIONS

1. Buying an experiment tooling is currently out of scope and but some risks counted are
- Incorporating non-open source code into our codebase
- Sending our data to 3rd parties
- Complications of incorporating of the bought tools into our backend

2. Product managers usually like:
- The ability to run, stop/pause experiments with ease
- Ability to get data quickly
- Standard funnel charts and analytics make things easier to analyze

3. Options discussed are Amplitude, Optimizely, LaunchDarkly

## GLEX (Gitlab experiment gem) & the experiment context

GLEX has a passionate energetic original developer and feature set
with a consistent design and with a lot of momentum. Engineers love
the (scientist-based) DSL. The decision to go with a gem or a library
matters less as the feature set is more or less stable. There seems to
be a hard learning curve, but the good thing is that most growth teams
have already done a few to a dozen experiments each. GLEX relies on a
standardized experiment context for snowplow tracking.

## EXMOD (Experimentation Module)

Experimentation module is used a lot within the acquisition/activation
and conversion team, and also expansion. It is developed in a collaborative fashion and it
shines whenever we need to measure namespace-based subscription metrics.
This is indispensable for experiment measurements based on real KPIs.


## ROADMAP

Set a target to standardize on GLEX. Enrich it to measure namespace-based
KPIs. Enhance the tooling around it probably with a UI.  Deprecate
EXMOD whenever all teams can run experiments that measure their
KPIs.

## TRACKING

We can use both Snowplow events and backend tables to measure the
interactivity and growth KPIS. Whenever product intelligence clears
the way to join them, by de-identification or a policy change, we can
also get rid of split-brain experiments and have a unified view.

## LEARNINGS

### Design/UX experiments

UX wants to be able to run frontend/copy-related experiments which are
indirectly affecting growth KPIs with ease. Like is a tooltip or a
banner better? Is "Buy" or "Purchase" or "Upgrade" better.

### Product management view on buy vs build

Product management finds both in-house toolings still limited compared to the buy options.

### Waterfall chart 

It may show the effect of each experiment on growth KPIs.

## Governance

For the time being the growth team should be developing the framework. But if growth product team is satisfied, we may get other teams within GitLab to run experiments too. At this stage, we may get a PM and a "Growth foundations" team member to manage experiment features.

epic.title: Growth Experimentation Roadmap

title: Handle non-committed changes when switching branches in the pipeline editor
description:
### Summary

When switching between branches on the pipeline editor using the branch switcher, changes are not persisted.
Switching away from a branch, then switching back to it, discards your changes and shows the config as it was when you first loaded the page.
This happens to both committed and non-committed changes.
This issue addresses the less severe of the two, non-committed changes.
Uncommitted changes will be fixed in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/331105

### Steps to reproduce

1. Enable the `pipeline_editor_branch_switcher` [feature flag](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/326189) (this is currently on for gitlab.com)
1. Open the pipeline editor on a project with a `.gitlab-ci.yaml` file. 
2. Make some changes to the config file (but don't commit them)
6. Switch away from that branch
7. Switch back to that branch. Your changes will have dissapeared.

Here's an example video of me encountering the problem.
![test_f](/uploads/544d97a7a9f698f3f85caeb035404751/test_f.mov)

### Example Project

This project already has the feature flag enabled and is specifically set up to test issues like this.
Please feel free to (ab)use it as needed to test this feature.

https://gitlab.com/samdbeckham/test

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

When switching between branches, changes are not persisted in the UI.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?
You are shown a warning telling you you will lose your unsaved changes.

## Proposal

### Expected Behavior

* When user switches branches after editing the content, a modal will pop up warning them of unsaved changes. (header: "You have unsaved changes"; body: "Unsaved changes will be lost")
* Clicking `Commit Changes` should close the modal and automatically scroll down to the commit form.
* Clicking `Switch Branches` will close the modal, switch to the target branch, and load the content of the target branch without saving changes.

title: Persist committed changes when switching branches in the pipeline editor
description:
### Summary

When switching between branches on the pipeline editor using the branch switcher, changes are not persisted.
Switching away from a branch, then switching back to it, discards your changes and shows the config as it was when you first loaded the page.
This happens to both committed and non-committed changes.
This issue addresses the more severe of the two, committed changes.
Uncommitted changes will be fixed in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/331107

### Steps to reproduce

1. Enable the `pipeline_editor_branch_switcher` [feature flag](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/326189) (this is currently on for gitlab.com)
1. Open the pipeline editor on a project with a `.gitlab-ci.yaml` file. 
2. Make some changes to the config file and commit those changes to a new branch.
3. This is the first point of failure, the new branch isn't available in the switcher. Until you…
4. refresh the page and select the branch you just created from the switcher.
5. Make some changes to that branch and commit them.
6. Switch away from that branch
7. switch back to that branch. Your changes will have dissapeared.

Here's an example video of me encountering the problem.
![test_f](/uploads/544d97a7a9f698f3f85caeb035404751/test_f.mov)

### Example Project

This project already has the feature flag enabled and is specifically set up to test issues like this.
Please feel free to (ab)use it as needed to test this feature.

https://gitlab.com/samdbeckham/test

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

When switching between branches, committed changes are not persisted in the UI.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

When switching between branches, the most up-to-date version of that branch should be shown.

### Possible fixes

Update the cache when committing changes. This keeps the performance benefits of only requesting the data when nessesary and fixes both the new branch problem and the persistant changes problem in one fell swoop.

title: [VSA][FE] - Change the rounding of the Total time to be closer to the actual sum
description:
### Problem
- The Overview time looks similar to the sum of all the stage times but it is rounded up/down in a way that makes it hard to know for sure if it is the sum. Take the following two Overview times for example. 

![Screen_Shot_2021-05-12_at_2.31.52_PM](/uploads/d46d7094f731d8fae487c11475b79f76/Screen_Shot_2021-05-12_at_2.31.52_PM.png)

![Screen_Shot_2021-05-12_at_2.32.07_PM](/uploads/054a28bef3afafe9c53af9cdde984e8e/Screen_Shot_2021-05-12_at_2.32.07_PM.png)

### Proposal
- Change the rounding of the `Total time` to be closer to the actual sum

The api returns the raw medians in seconds, we then sum them and use [timeSummaryForPathNavigation](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/app/assets/javascripts/analytics/cycle_analytics/utils.js#L360) to convert the value into a friendly number and unit. It looks like the `parseSeconds` method is returning the time breakdown (weeks/days/hours etc) after rounding down.

* [x] Add license subscription_id to Usage Ping https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/51601 `@alinamihaila`

 `license_subscription_id=>""`

## How to generate Usage Ping for GtiLab.com

### Through detached screen session

#### Prerequisites

[Docs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/usage_ping/#generating-and-troubleshooting-usage-ping)

1. make sure the key is added to the ssh agent locally
 `ssh-add `

#### Triggering
1. Run `ssh-add` to add the key to the agent
1. Connect to bastion with agent forwarding `$ ssh -A lb-bastion.gprd.gitlab.com `
1. Create named screen `$ screen -S <username>_usage_ping_<date>`
1. Connect to console host `$ ssh $USER-rails@console-01-sv-gprd.c.gitlab-production.internal`
1. Run `SubmitUsagePingService.new.execute` 
1. Detach from screen `ctrl + a, ctrl + d`
1. Exit from bastion `$ exit`

#### Verification (After approx 30 hours)

1. Reconnect to bastion `$ ssh -A lb-bastion.gprd.gitlab.com `
1. Find your screen session `$ screen -ls`
1. Attach to your screen session `$ screen -x 14226.mwawrzyniak_usage_ping_2021_01_22`
1. Check the last payload in `raw_usage_data` table: `RawUsageData.last.payload`
1. Check the when the payload was sent `RawUsageData.last.sent_at`

#### Stop Usage Ping process

Record the host the usage ping is generated

Connect to host generating usage ping

user name: `amihaila` 

```
ssh bastion-01-inf-gprd.c.gitlab-production.internal
```

```
sudo -u <username> screen -ls 
sudo -u <username> screen -r

# or

ps faux | grep <username>

# find process and kill it
```

### Usage Ping process triggering (through long running ssh session) 

1. Connect to  `gprd` rails console
1. Run `SubmitUsagePingService.new.execute` this will take more than 30 hours.
1. Check the last payload in `raw_usage_data` table: `RawUsageData.last.payload`
1. Check the when the payload was sent `RawUsageData.last.sent_at`


```
SubmitUsagePingService.new.execute

# Get the payload
RawUsageData.last.payload

# Time when payload was sent to VersionsAppp
RawUsageData.last.sent_at
```

## How to check Usage Ping in VersionsApp

1. In versions app console RawUsageData.find(uuid: '')
1. In Rails console, check the related `RawUsageData` object
1. Or in VersionsApp UI https://version.gitlab.com/usage_data/usage_data_id

```ruby

/bin/herokuish procfile exec rails console

puts UsageData.select(:recorded_at, :app_server_type).where(hostname: 'gitlab.com', uuid: 'ea8bf810-1d6f-4a6a-b4fd-93e8cbd8b57f').order('id desc').limit(5).to_json

puts UsageData.find(21635202).raw_usage_data.payload.to_json
```

### Monitoring events tracked using Redis HLL 


### What to do if you get mentioned?

In this issue we keep the track of new metrics added to usage ping and metrics that are timing out.

If you get mentioned please check the failing metric and open an optimization issue.

title: Allowlist Wiki and README.md for Mermaid limits
description:
### Summary

Current limitations on Mermaid rendering, 2K total characters per page OR 50 blocks, whichever happens first, helps in preventing a DoS attack on all pages where we can render GFM.

This is non-ideal for pages like Wikis where

1. There is no user-generated content.
2. The mermaid diagrams are better formatted and can contain `css` styles, which quickly fills up the 2K character quota. (See comment https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/60490#note_575468577)

### Security concerns

Since editing and creating a Wiki or `Readme.md` file requires a Developer or higher role, we can trust the actor to not abuse the uplifted limits. 

### Proposal

Maintain an allowlist of all the pages where we can trust the actor, and uplift all limits on the Mermaid diagram blocks.

--------

MR where this got originated: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/60490

cc: @donaldcook @cmaxim 

Also looping in @disenchant

title: [Feature flag] Rollout of `use_specialized_worker_for_project_auth_recalculation`
description:
<!-- Title suggestion: [Feature flag] Enable description of feature -->

## Summary

This issue is to rollout [the feature](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/60904) on production,
that is currently behind the `use_specialized_worker_for_project_auth_recalculation` feature flag.

Introduced with https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/60904

<!-- Short description of what the feature is about and link to relevant other issues. -->

## Owners

- Team: Manage::Access
- Most appropriate slack channel to reach out to: `#g_manage_access`
- Best individual to reach out to: Manoj M J
- PM: Melissa Ushakov

## Stakeholders

<!--
Are there any other stages or teams involved that need to be kept in the loop?

- Name of a PM
- The Support Team
- The Delivery Team
-->

## The Rollout Plan

- Partial Rollout on GitLab.com with testing groups
- Rollout on GitLab.com for a certain period (How long)
- Percentage Rollout on GitLab.com
- Rollout Feature for everyone as soon as it's ready

<!-- Which dashboards from https://dashboards.gitlab.net are most relevant? Sentry errors reports can also be useful to review -->

## Testing Groups/Projects/Users

<!-- If applicable, any groups/projects that are happy to have this feature turned on early. Some organizations may wish to test big changes they are interested in with a small subset of users ahead of time for example. -->

- `gitlab-org/gitlab` project
- `gitlab-org`/`gitlab-com` groups
- ...


## Expectations

### What are we expecting to happen?

<!-- Describe the expected outcome when rolling out this feature -->

### What might happen if this goes wrong?

<!-- Should the feature flag be turned off? Any MRs that need to be rolled back? Communication that needs to happen? What are some things you can think of that could go wrong - data loss or broken pages? -->

### What can we monitor to detect problems with this?

<!-- Which dashboards from https://dashboards.gitlab.net are most relevant? -->

## Rollout Steps

### Rollout on non-production environments

- [x] Ensure that the feature MRs have been deployed to non-production environments.
    - [x] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-your-feature>`
- [x] Enable the feature globally on non-production environments.
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> true --dev`
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> true --staging`
- [x] Verify that the feature works as expected. Posting the QA result in this issue is preferable.

### Preparation before production rollout

- [x] Ensure that the feature MRs have been deployed to both production and canary.
    - [x] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-your-feature>`
- [x] Check if the feature flag change needs to be accompanied with a
  [change management issue](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/change-management/#feature-flags-and-the-change-management-process).
  Cross link the issue here if it does.
- [x] Ensure that you or a representative in development can be available for at least 2 hours after feature flag updates in production.
  If a different developer will be covering, or an exception is needed, please inform the oncall SRE by using the `@sre-oncall` Slack alias.
- [ ] Ensure that documentation has been updated ([More info](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/feature_flags.html#features-that-became-enabled-by-default)).
- [ ] Announce on [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) an estimated time this will be enabled on GitLab.com.
- [ ] If the feature flag in code has [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), enable it on GitLab.com for [testing groups/projects](#testing-groupsprojectsusers).
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set --<actor-type>=<actor> <feature-flag-name> true`
- [ ] Verify that the feature works as expected. Posting the QA result in this issue is preferable.

### Global rollout on production

- [x] [Incrementally roll out](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#process) the feature.
  - If the feature flag in code has [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), perform **actor-based** rollout.
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> <rollout-percentage> --actors`
  - If the feature flag in code does **NOT** have [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), perform time-based rollout (**random** rollout).
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> <rollout-percentage>`
  - Enable the feature globally on production environment.
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> true`
- [ ] Announce on [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) that the feature has been globally enabled.
- [ ] Cross-post chatops slack command to `#support_gitlab-com`.
  ([more guidance when this is necessary in the dev docs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#communicate-the-change)) and in your team channel
- [ ] Wait for [at least one day for the verification term](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release).

### (Optional) Release the feature with the feature flag

If you're still unsure whether the feature is [deemed stable](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release)
but want to release it in the current milestone, you can change the default state of the feature flag to be enabled.
To do so, follow these steps:

- [ ] Create a merge request with the following changes. Ask for review and merge it.
    - [ ] Set the `default_enabled` attribute in [the feature flag definition](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-flag-definition-and-validation) to `true`.
    - [ ] Create [a changelog entry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#changelog).
- [ ] Ensure that the above MR has been deployed to both production and canary.
      If the merge request was deployed before [the code cutoff](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/releases/#self-managed-releases-1),
      the feature can be officially announced in a release blog post.
    - [ ] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit>`
- [ ] Close [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) to indicate the feature will be released in the current milestone.

**WARNING:** This approach has the downside that it makes it difficult for us to
[clean up](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up) the flag.
For example, on-premise users could disable the feature on their GitLab instance. But when you
remove the flag at some point, they suddenly see the feature as enabled and they can't roll it back
to the previous behavior. To avoid this potential breaking change, use this approach only for urgent
matters.

### Release the feature

After the feature has been [deemed stable](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release),
the [clean up](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up)
should be done as soon as possible to permanently enable the feature and reduce complexity in the
codebase.

<!-- The checklist here is to help stakeholders keep track of the feature flag status -->
- [x] Create a merge request to remove `<feature-flag-name>` feature flag. Ask for review and merge it.
    - [x] Remove all references to the feature flag from the codebase.
    - [x] Remove the YAML definitions for the feature from the repository.
    - [x] Create [a changelog entry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#changelog).
- [x] Ensure that the above MR has been deployed to both production and canary.
      If the merge request was deployed before [the code cutoff](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/releases/#self-managed-releases-1),
      the feature can be officially announced in a release blog post.
    - [x] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit>`
- [x] Close [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) to indicate the feature will be released in the current milestone.
- [x] Clean up the feature flag from all environments by running these chatops command in `#production` channel:
    - [x] `/chatops run feature delete <feature-flag-name> --dev`
    - [x] `/chatops run feature delete <feature-flag-name> --staging`
    - [x] `/chatops run feature delete <feature-flag-name>`
- [x] Close this rollout issue.

## Rollback Steps

- [ ] This feature can be disabled by running the following Chatops command:

```
/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> false
```

title: Update job output with vulnerability count including sub-faults
description:
### Problem

The API Security based analyzers output the total vulnerability count in the job output. However, this output doesn't take into account sub-faults. The count may be lower than is reported via the security report.

Example: `Testing completed successfully, 39 issues detected.`

### Proposal

Update the fault count returned by the REST API to include the correct count with sub-faults.

Tasks:

1. [ ] Update return value to include sub-faults
1. [ ] Publish new container

title: Feature Flags API has "stickiness" values as uppercase text, however UnleaseClient expects camelCase
description:
### Summary

Trying to use a "rollout" strategy leads to errors in the UnleashClient integration (python):


### Steps to reproduce

1. create a feature flag with a "Percent rollout" strategy, based on "User ID"
2. use UnleashClient (4.2.0) to check the feature-flag
3. error: `Error checking feature flag: 'USERID'`

### Example Project

https://gitlab.com/ofer.koren/gitlab/-/feature_flags/1/edit

```pythonfrom UnleashClient import UnleashClient
client=UnleashClient(
        url="https://gitlab.com/api/v4/feature_flags/unleash/24758814",
        app_name='dev',
        environment='tlv',
        disable_metrics=True,
        disable_registration=True,
        instance_id="GZXM3DCq34iHAzHX47jc")
client.initialize_client()
client.is_enabled("demo-flag", dict(userId='my-user'))
```
```
Error checking feature flag: 'USERID'
```

Debugging through the UnleashClient code, it's apparent that `stickiness` is expected to be `userId` instead of `USERID`.

https://github.com/Unleash/unleash-client-python/blob/f85ca073299d8b139d6c4e7caa1a9d4c5ae24192/UnleashClient/strategies/GradualRolloutUserId.py#L31



### What is the current *bug* behavior?

UnleashClient errors when checking on the feature flag:
```
Error checking feature flag: 'USERID'
```


### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

no errors

title: Follow-up from "Jira Connect: show all namespaces when search term length < 3"
description:
The following discussion from !61099 should be addressed:

- [ ] @pgascouvaillancourt started a [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/61099#note_574911812):  (+3 comments)

Empty strings, or search terms with one or two characters, are essentially considered identical in the component's logic. This means resetting the `page` on every user input might not be the best UX because we'll bring them back to the first page even in cases where the query doesn't actually change.

Perhaps we could do the following:

1. `onGroupSearch` does not modify `this.page`.
1. Create a `search` computed property to wrap the term's length logic (`searchTerm?.length < MINIMUM_SEARCH_TERM_LENGTH ? '' : searchTerm`).
1. Define a watcher that resets `page` whenever the `search` computed property changes.
1. `loadGroups` leverages the computed property in the fetch query.

### Availability & Testing

Suggestion: add a [frontend integration test](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/testing_guide/testing_levels.html#frontend-integration-tests) that asserts on the presence/content of an outbound request when changing the searchTerm with a length from (1...2) to (+3).

title: Migrate security-report-download-dropdown in security_reports_app.vue to use newer merge-request-artifact-download component Part 2
description:
| Part | Issue | Description
| ------ | ------ | ----- |
| 1 | https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/330429 | Move EE code to CE update existing usages
| 2 | https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/331025 | Swap out component for newer component <-- This one

## Part 1 Implementation Plan
https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/330429

## Part 2 Implementation Plan
- In https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/assets/javascripts/vue_shared/security_reports/security_reports_app.vue#L201 swap out to use merge_request_artifact_download

~~- Remove graphQL query and `apollo` object from the component. The same query exists in `merge_request_artifact_download.vue`. We only need to pass in the following props: `reportType`, `targetProjectFullPath`, and `mrIid`~~

(The above step was removed because the apollo/graphql fetch logic lives in the child component. Turns out the parent component also needs access to the same data to figure out if the `v-if` that renders the child component is true. The child component won't mount and fetch the data until the parent container template has `v-if` true. So we have a circular dependency.

The way Apollo + Cache shares state between components without VueX is to share data with overlapping GraphQL queries. In this case, we have the same data consumed in the parent and child component. The child component is used elsewhere in the codebase as it's own component so passing in props doesn't make sense. I believe having the query in the parent and child component in this edge case is not bad code quality because this is the pattern Apollo Cache uses to share global state. The **cache** is the single source of truth even for components at different levels of being nested.

Both queries are the same, but the data is cached, so there is no performance hit of 2 roundtrip queries.

title: Vulnerabilities / Jira integration doesn't work with Jira "Next Gen" projects
description:
### Summary The new Vulnerability Management feature that allows creating a Jira issue directly from a vulnerability record works perfectly with Jira Classic ("Company-managed software") projects. However, it looks like it does not work at all with Jira Next Gen ("Team-managed software") projects. [See this video](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1ixmQ-GYeUfzou7bep_8qHXxdtb6lmTXn/view?usp=sharing) for a demo of the error behavior. One relevant detail is the issue type list seems incorrect when configuring a Next Gen project on the GitLab side. The issue list is supposed to be dynamic. It returns the expected list for Classic projects. However, for Next Gen projects, the issues never match what is configured on the Jira side. This seems directly related to what causes the error. The Jira issue IDs used for the available issue types on Next Gen projects all appear to be incorrect. The issue IDs seem to match those that are available when using Classic projects. This seems to be the cause of the error. If you manually update the URL of the new Jira issue after you get the error with a correct issue ID for a Next Gen project, it works as expected. ### Steps to reproduce 1. Configure and enable a Jira integration (`Settings` → `Integrations`) for your GitLab project. 1. Enter a `Jira project key` corresponding to a Next Gen Jira project. 1. Save changes or Test settings to make sure configuration is correct. 1. Check the `Enable Jira issues creation from vulnerabilities` option. 1. Hit the "refresh" button next to the `Jira issue types` dropdown 1. This should dynamically pull all configured issue types on the Jira project specified above. 1. Note that for Next Gen projects, the list likely will NOT accurately reflect the project's configured issue types if viewed in Jira's project settings 1. Select any Jira issue type and Save changes. 1. Go to `Security & Compliance` → `Vulnerability Report` for the same project. 1. Click the vulnerability name/description on any vulnerability list entry to view the vulnerability record (details page). 1. Click the `Create Jira issue` button to open a new window. Note the Jira error about invalid Issue type. ### Example Project https://gitlab.com/matt_wilson/simply-simple-notes/ (ask @matt_wilson for access) Test Jira instance: https://gitlab-stage-protect.atlassian.net/ It is possible the wrong API call is being used to fetch the Jira Issue types. The following API call will return an array of configured Issue types for both Class and Next Gen projects: https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/jira/platform/rest/v3/api-group-projects/#api-rest-api-3-project-projectidorkey-get Verify this by seeing the results from two test projects: * Next Gen: https://gitlab-stage-protect.atlassian.net/rest/api/3/project/10002/ * Classic: https://gitlab-stage-protect.atlassian.net/rest/api/3/project/10003/ ### What is the current *bug* behavior? Trying to create a Jira issue from a GitLab vulnerability when the configured Jira project is a Next Gen type always results in an error message that the issue type is invalid (see video). ### What is the expected *correct* behavior? Creating Jira issues from vulnerabilities should work the same for both Classic and Next Gen projects. ### Relevant logs and/or screenshots [Video of the error behavior](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1ixmQ-GYeUfzou7bep_8qHXxdtb6lmTXn/view?usp=sharing) ### Output of checks #### Results of GitLab environment info
Expand for output related to GitLab environment info 

(For installations with omnibus-gitlab package run and paste the output of:
`sudo gitlab-rake gitlab:env:info`)

(For installations from source run and paste the output of:
`sudo -u git -H bundle exec rake gitlab:env:info RAILS_ENV=production`)
#### Results of GitLab application Check
Expand for output related to the GitLab application check 

(For installations with omnibus-gitlab package run and paste the output of:
`sudo gitlab-rake gitlab:check SANITIZE=true`)

(For installations from source run and paste the output of:
`sudo -u git -H bundle exec rake gitlab:check RAILS_ENV=production SANITIZE=true`)

(we will only investigate if the tests are passing)
### Possible fixes * ~backend Update `project_issuetype_scheme_ids` in `ee/app/models/project_services/ee/jira_service.rb` to not do anything when Jira project style is `next-gen` * ~backend Update `project_issuetype_ids` in `ee/app/models/project_services/ee/jira_service.rb` to handle Next Gen JIRA projects by making a call to `https://.atlassian.net/rest/api/3/project/` and using `issueTypes`

title: Extract package metadata for npm packages
description:
<!-- triage-serverless v3 PLEASE DO NOT REMOVE THIS SECTION -->
*This page may contain information related to upcoming products, features and functionality.
It is important to note that the information presented is for informational purposes only, so please do not rely on the information for purchasing or planning purposes.
Just like with all projects, the items mentioned on the page are subject to change or delay, and the development, release, and timing of any products, features, or functionality remain at the sole discretion of GitLab Inc.*
<!-- triage-serverless v3 PLEASE DO NOT REMOVE THIS SECTION -->
### Release notes

You are using the GitLab Package Registry to publish and share your node dependencies right alongside your source code and pipelines. Convenient huh? Well what hasn't been convenient is that not all of the metadata from the package.json is available in the Package Registry user interface. That makes it hard to verify the package quickly, which is really what we want the UI to help with. 

While we are still working on making that data available in the API and searchable (read more about it in the epic: https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/5151), we thought a solid first iteration was to simply display the contents of the file in the UI. 

Now when you navigate to the package details page, you can view the contents of the `package.json` file right in the UI. 

### Problem to solve

When an npm package is uploaded to the GitLab Package Registry it includes a `package.json` which is packaged in a tar.gz file. The `package.json` contains important metadata for a given package. This data is used to validate that you are using the correct package or to verify that it was built correctly. However, only a limited subset of this data is currently displayed in the Package Registry UI. This makes it hard for node developers to verify their dependencies.

### Proposal

When an npm package is uploaded, the backend should pass a `metadata_file` to the front end, so the file can be displayed in the user interface. 

#### Data to extract 
(reference: https://docs.npmjs.com/cli/v6/configuring-npm/package-json

| Metadata             |
|--------------------------|
| name                     |
| version                  |
| description              |
| keywords                 |
| homepage                 |
| bugs                     |
| license                  |
| people                   |
| people.author            |
| people.author.name       |
| people.author.email      |
| people.author.url        |
| people.contributor       |
| people.contributor.name  |
| people.contributor.email |
| people.contributor.url   |
| funding                  |
| files                    |
| main                     |
| browser                  |
| bin                      |
| man                      |
| directories              |
| directories.lib          |
| directories.bin          |
| directories.man          |
| directories.doc          |
| directories.example      |
| directories.test         |
| repository               |
| scripts                  |
| config                   |
| dependencies             |
| engines                  |
| engineStrict             |
| os                       |
| cpu                      |
| preferGlobal             |
| private                  |
| publishConfig            |
| ng-update   (needed by angular)             |

title: Logic for priority reindexing
description:
As described in the parent epic there are certain scenarios where we want to be able to rebuild an indexes in a more targeted fashion on GitLab.com: For example, we might have identified a pathology in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/218410#note_571485758 and want to re-create the index. Another reason to do a targeted rebuild is an INVALID index left behind and similar situations.

This issue focuses on creating priority reindexing heuristic. If there is an entry in the queue, then it takes priority. If the queue is empty then default to using the bloat heuristic.

title: Add Conan packages to the `list project dependencies` API
description:
### Context

The [List Project Dependencies API call](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/dependencies.html#list-project-dependencies) has an optional attribute for `package_manager`. I.e. calling `GET /projects/:id/dependencies?package_manager=npm` will only show results for `npm` packages.

Conan dependency management has been supported since [#225218](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/225218), and Conan packages do show up in the full results if the `package_manager` attribute is not used, however there is still no `package_manager` option to show only `conan` results.

### Proposal

Update the API to allow passing `conan` as a `package_manager` attribute, so that I can quickly filter my dependencies list on my C/C++ dependencies.

### Implementation Plan

1. Add `conan` to the [FILTER_PACKAGE_MANAGERS_VALUES](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/6d968026dc1/ee/app/services/security/dependency_list_service.rb#L7-7) variable:

   ```diff
   -    FILTER_PACKAGE_MANAGERS_VALUES = %w(bundler yarn npm maven composer pip).freeze
   +    FILTER_PACKAGE_MANAGERS_VALUES = %w(bundler yarn npm maven composer pip conan).freeze
   ```
1. Add a test to [Security::DependencyListService](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/6d968026dc1/ee/spec/services/security/dependency_list_service_spec.rb#L40-40) to verify that the above change works as expected

title: LDAP synchronization should warn before it kills direct member list
description:
## Issue
Opening as feature as per discussion in https://federal-support.gitlab.com/hc/en-us/requests/868

Scenario: we have an existing gitlab self-managed server with LDAP configured.  We have an existing gitlab "group" configured with direct members.  We decide to add additional users to the gitlab "group" via an LDAP configuration within the GUI.  We add an LDAP group to the gitlab group with "maintainer" access and synchronize.  All the existing direct members outside of the LDAP group lose their access!

It would be nice if the GUI provided a warning about the direct members being lost before applying in this scenario.

Note that this is the documented behavior.  However, from a UI/UX perspective, it's usually a good idea for GUIs to warn about dangerous actions.  This is an example of the "principle of least surprise".

## Proposal

Add a warning message 

> Synchronizing groups using LDAP causes all users outside of the LDAP group to lose their permissions. Are you sure you want to continue?

User will have the option to continue or to cancel this action

#### Visuals
![Iteration_3](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/uploads/eaf26603e3b1b92f8933d44a6a66f247/Iteration_3.png)

title: Design: Incident timelines
description:
### Scope of issue

As part of our [Monitor Vision](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/monitor/monitor/-/issues/41) issue, we defined four vision items we wanted to tackle in the upcoming year: incident timelines, incident reporting, more granular permissions and incident dashboards. 

This issue is for tackling the first item on the list: incident timelines. The goal here would be to refine a design for incident timelines. When this design is complete, we'll make a plan for validating the proposed designs.

### Original vision designs

Goal: Allow people to easily create an editable timeline on incidents.

| Add timeline tab + way to easily add comment items to timeline | Timeline view | Allow for adding/sorting of timeline view | Timeline actions (starring, editing, deleting) | Timeline editing close-up |
| ------ | ------ | ------ | ------ | ------ |

### WIP High Fidelity Mock-Ups

| ------ | ------ | ------ | 
| ![Mobile](/uploads/b03022661b0224ecff39d1b2c3d0bbe2/Mobile.png) | ![Dropdown](/uploads/d25ef9e4ddc44d9d283752c741816975/Dropdown.png)| ![Mobile_modal](/uploads/5f2271f79fca466b67c9b3abe9f4f3ee/Mobile_modal.png) |

More actions menu on mobile revealed on tapping any list item. Button disappears when the user taps on another row, or when they tap again on the highlighted row. Background stays highlighted in blue when button is visible.

Click through [prototype link](https://www.figma.com/proto/01efUzilO8y3FZndx4Kt14/Incident-timelines-gitlab-com-and-330901?node-id=63%3A9104&scaling=min-zoom&page-id=63%3A342)

Figma file for [timelines](https://www.figma.com/file/01efUzilO8y3FZndx4Kt14/Incident-timelines-gitlab-com-and-330901?node-id=63%3A342), specifically

### Follow-up questions

There are a few unknowns here that we'll probably need to investigate further before implementing, either as part of the solution validation process or as part of a technical spike to determine the best path forward. 

1. Timezone that we want to present the timeline in. MVC options - either user's local time or UTC. Plan is to ask for feedback about this during solution validation. Our SRE team [prefers UTC](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/330901#note_603108775) so, that would probably be what we want to use for the MVC.
2. Which bits of information we can easily pull into the timeline in both the short and longer terms. We assume it would be nice to have some alert and incident activity feed items (such as alert and incident start times and status changes) pulled into the feed automatically, but it would probably be better if we didn't have to automatically pull in all of the feed items, as not all will be relevant. We'll need some additional technical investigation into what's possible. If we can't easily distinguish between activity feed items, our SRE team is okay with all system notes being pulled in if need be, since they can easily be deleted. They would also want alert system notes pulled in, too, if possible.

### Out-of-scope for the MVC
Slash command to add an item to the timeline, meaning the ability to add a comment to the timeline as it's being submitted rather than retroactively. For now, we'll consider this as being outside of the scope for the MVC but, it would also be nice to have a plan for this as the [SRE team](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/330901#note_603108775) would be very interested in this functionality being available. We can also gather additional feedback to see if it is, indeed, an essential part of the MVC experience.

title: GitLab Migration - More fine-grained status for group bulk imports
description:
## Problem to solve

Per [this comment](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/61097#note_568489261), when [migrating Groups in bulk](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/300098), all top-level groups are imported in one bulk batch. This user experience is shown in [this video](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/61097#video). 

This means that if we have `group1`, `group2`, and `group3` on the page and click `Import all` - their statuses will **always be in sync** for all three groups. Even when all related imports for i.e. `group1` are completed, the status for `group1` will remain `Importing...` until all the other groups in the same batch are completed.

## Proposed solution

It would be useful to have a more fine-grained status. This can be accomplished by either having separate statues for each group in the batch, or by having separate batches for the top-level groups.

title: Investigation: Pre-generate information used in rendering a merge request
description:
# Context

In the Brainstorming issue, @kerrizor wrote:

> Here's a wild idea.
> 
> First -- what's the fastest possible page?
> 
> One that is entirely served from a CDN or memory cache.
> 
> So...
> 
> ![image](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/uploads/f73631513ec39221cb32d096db729e9d/image.png)
> 
> What if we were more aggressive about not just caching content, but about working to have an answer for a user's "question" before they even ask it? We make so much of our site up-to-the-millisecond accurate, but not all information A) needs that accuracy or B) is important enough to add delay the user's overall experience for the sake of accuracy.
> 
> Obviously, I'm not saying *literally* "no more DB queries" but I think we should take a long, hard look at the information we run around fetching from DB/Gitaly, and see what we can pre-generate, to target, say, the 90% use case of the information, or of information where inaccuracies caused by small delays is less meaningful.
> 
> To do this, we would need to shift to thinking about our work from reactive to proactive generation, which *trends* towards an event-driven model.
> 
> For example.. at the moment we create a merge request, we have a fair idea of all the various checks and rules that might prevent that MR from being mergeable. Why waste computational cycles rechecking the mergeability state of the MR with every page load, and instead default it to an "unmergeable" state and have workers, triggered by the event of MR creation, confirm their own subsystems as a "go" asynchronously? Why do so much work within the request cycle, when we can move it out-of-band? **Work we don't do is cheaper than work we do, but work we do that we don't make the user sit around waiting for is also pretty cheap.**


# What's next?

This proposal gathered some support and seems like it could use some more investigation into its feasibility.

Namely:

* What are the heaviest operations in the MR that we can pre-calculate accurately?
* Can we ensure updating/invalidating that calculation in a way that doesn't affect UX?
* If it does affect UX, is it acceptable?
* (please add)

description:
### Context

We've done a lot of work to create GraphQL APIs for the GitLab Package Registry. With that [work](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/285467) wrapping up in 14.1, it would be great to start updating the Package Registry UI to leverage the new API. Refactor the package details page from using a mix of controllers/rest API to use the new GraphQL API.

title: Convert Package List page to use Apollo/Graphql
description:
### Context

We've done a lot of work to create GraphQL APIs for the GitLab Package Registry. With that [work](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/285467) wrapping up in 14.1, it would be great to start updating the Package Registry UI to leverage the new API. This will help with performance and help to unblock future feature development. 

### Proposal
Refactor the ~frontend code from using a mix of rest API and controllers to just use the new GraphqQL API.

## Testing and Availability

We have several end-to-end tests that rely/visit the package list page. These tests should be passing after implementing this conversion. To verify that we run `package-and-qa` on the MRs. No refactoring on end-to-end tests should be needed.

title: Use instrumented classes in Usage Ping
description:
Use instrumentation classes defined in metrics definitions and `usage_data.rb` to build the Usage Ping Payload

This will allow us use instrumentation classes for a limited type of metrics. See https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/6118 for adding more support


### Proposed roadmap

1. [ ] add `add_metric(instrumentation)` method to `usage_data.rb`
1. [ ] Use the existing instrumentation classes in `usage_data.rb`
1. [ ] overite `add_metric(instrumentation)` in usage_data_queries.rb in order to continue support for generating metrics queries
1. [ ] overite `add_metric(instrumentation)` for naming suggestions in order to continue support for metrics suggestions
1. [ ] overite `add_metric(instrumentation)` for `lib/gitlab/usage_data_non_sql_metrics.rb` to continue support for non SQL metrics API

**Testing considerations**:

Metrics migrated to instrumentation classes in usage_data.rb:

- uuid
- hostname
- counts.issues
- count.boards
- usage_activity_by_stage.plan.issues
- usage_activity_by_stage_monthly.plan.issues

* Ensure JSON payload generated with `SubmitUsagePingService` is generating without any errors.
* Correspondent RawUsageData is created correctly
* Payload is submitted to version app 
   ```ruby
   RawUsageData.count
   SubmitUsagePingService.new.execute
   RawUsageData.count
   
   # inspect payload
  payload = RawUsageData.last.payload
  payload['uuid']
  payload['hostname']
  payload['counts']['issues']
  payload['counts']['boards']
  payload['usage_activity_by_stage']['plan']['issues']
  payload['usage_activity_by_stage_monthly']['plan']['issues']
   ```
* Ensure we can generate the metrics queries `bundle exec rake gitlab:usage_data:dump_sql_in_yaml`
* Ensure non SQL usage data is working correct `Gitlab::UsageDataNonSqlMetrics.uncached_data `
* Name suggestions are correct: ` Gitlab::Usage::Metrics::NamesSuggestions::Generator.generate("counts.boards")`

title: Remove the `OpenProjectService` integration
description:
## About

This issue came out of this discussion https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/329410#note_563428794.

The `OpenProjectService` integration is incomplete https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/15847#note_388912720. As ~"group::ecosystem" are unlikely to complete it at present https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/15847#note_422065412 we should remove it. 

Note, this service may get renamed to `Integrations::OpenProject` as part of https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/201855 simply to be able to delete the `project_services` directory.

## Proposal

We should revert https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/28012, or if the MR is unrevertable, remove all of the relevant code.

We should also search through the codebase for `OpenProject` and `open_project` and clean up any references.

We should update the description of https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/15847 with this information and link to the original MR so in future, the work can be jump-started if a community contributor wishes to work on it.

title: Add created_at to the Billable Members API
description:
<!-- This issue template can be used a great starting point for feature requests. The last section "Release notes" can be used as a summary of the feature and is also required if you want to have your release post blog MR auto generated using the release post item generator:  https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/blog/release-posts/#release-post-item-generator. The remaining sections are the backbone for every feature in GitLab. -->

### Release notes 

<!-- What is the problem and solution you're proposing? This content sets the overall vision for the feature and serves as the release notes that will populate in various places, including the [release post blog](https://about.gitlab.com/releases/categories/releases/) and [Gitlab project releases](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/releases). " -->

### Problem to solve 

Gitlab.com customers have no way of understanding when a given user account was provisioned.

### Proposal 

Add the `created_at` field to the BillableMember entity and return as part of our billable members API resource.


### Intended users

Who will use this feature? If known, include any of the following: types of users (e.g. Developer), personas, or specific company roles (e.g. Release Manager). It's okay to write "Unknown" and fill this field in later.

Personas are described at https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/

* [Sam (Security Analyst)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sam-security-analyst)

title: Add link to Jira configuration in Jira Issues sidebar popout
description:
### Proposal

Add a **Configuration** (or similar) item to the **Jira Issues** nav popout, that links to the Project-level Jira Configuration: 

![Screen_Shot_2021-05-13_at_11.11.28_am](/uploads/3aef58646639db36550ce59feee37f87/Screen_Shot_2021-05-13_at_11.11.28_am.png)

### Why

I found myself wanting to view/change the Jira configuration for my project, and was frustrated that there wasn't a link to do so from the **Jira**/**Jira Issues** nav item in the left sidebar.

Users whose Gitlab instance uses Group or Instance-level Jira configuration may want to change the configuration for an individual project, but have to navigate to a different nav item **Settings > Integrations > Jira** to do so. This might be confusing to users who are unfamiliar with the **Integrations** section.

title: change DS and LC icons
description:
### Release notes 

### Problem to solve 

The “dash” icon is used in various MR widgets, but its meaning is not clear: Is everything is ok? Is it a progress bar? A null result?

The `x` and `√` icons used here are also supposed to be reserved for pipeline status. Current icons:

![image](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/uploads/401f4411978bac7ea0dddcf01c8fbcd3/image.png)

See https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/296513#note_570178231 for more.

### Proposal 

Update our icons in the Secure MR widget for DS and LC to be the circular icons. Also indent the icons to match the latest update in the other security widgets (see [this MR](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/56768)).

Proposed design:

![image](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/uploads/7b99588598d2ac2082a872a2e9147b4d/image.png)

* Uses 8px spacing between icon and text

### Documentation

Update user doc images as needed

### Availability & Testing

you may need to update tests? unlikely but check

### Is this a cross-stage feature?

We are about to no longer match the rest of ~"devops::secure" and ~"devops::protect" 

Do the other PMs want us to update to the round-bubble icons for them too?

@tmccaslin 
@derekferguson 
@sam.white 


## Implementation Plan

- [x] Update SVG icons here https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/v14.0.0-rc42-ee/app/assets/javascripts/reports/components/issue_status_icon.vue#L23

- [x] Change the following:

`status_failed_borderless` -> `status-failed`

`status_success_borderless` -> `status-success`

`dash` -> `status-alert`
- [x] Change `gl-mr-3` to `gl-mr-2` in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/v14.0.0-rc42-ee/app/assets/javascripts/reports/components/report_item.vue#L55
- [ ] Update unit tests
- [ ] Verify all usages of `issue_status_icon` below:

title: REST services API returns unsaved service objects
description:
### Summary

## About

The REST `GET projects/:id/services/:slug` API returns unsaved service objects. For example https://gitlab.com/api/v4/projects/17595187/services/asana (note the `"id": null`):

```
{
"id": null,
"title": "Asana",
"slug": "asana",
"created_at": null,
"updated_at": null,
"active": false,
"commit_events": true,
"push_events": true,
"issues_events": true,
"confidential_issues_events": true,
"merge_requests_events": true,
"tag_push_events": true,
"note_events": true,
"confidential_note_events": true,
"pipeline_events": true,
"wiki_page_events": true,
"job_events": true,
"comment_on_event_enabled": true,
"properties": {}
}
```

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

The API should return a `404` response when a project does not have the service.

### Possible fixes

We should replace [`Project#find_or_initialize_service`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/dc000c6f436f047ac256f58273b909d3575f2d1f/lib/api/services.rb#L128) with `Project#integrations#by_type` to scope existing integrations.

title: [VSA][FE] - Explain the duration shown next to Overview
description:
### Overview

The Overview stage shows a measure of time. There is no explanation in the UI or user docs that explains how that is calculated or what it means. Each of the other stages have a tooltip explaining the start and end event used to calculate the stage duration.

### Problems to address
- The meaning of the Overview time is unclear and a user has to guess what it means
- The Overview time could easily be mistaken for Lead Time (median time from issue created to issue closed)
- The Overview time looks similar to the sum of all the stage times but it is rounded up/down in a way that makes it hard to know for sure if it is the sum. Take the following two Overview times for example. 

![Screen_Shot_2021-05-12_at_2.31.52_PM](/uploads/d46d7094f731d8fae487c11475b79f76/Screen_Shot_2021-05-12_at_2.31.52_PM.png)

![Screen_Shot_2021-05-12_at_2.32.07_PM](/uploads/054a28bef3afafe9c53af9cdde984e8e/Screen_Shot_2021-05-12_at_2.32.07_PM.png)

### Proposal for this issue
- [ ] Add a tooltip for Overview that explains how the time is calculated.
- [ ] Explain the `Total time` in the user documentation

#### Out of scope (separate issue)
-  Change the rounding of the `Total time` to be closer to the actual sum (see https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/331099 for more details)

epic.title: [VSA] Usability improvements

title: [feature flag] remove merge_base_pipeline_for_metrics_comparison
description:
<!-- Title suggestion:  -->

## Summary

This issue is to rollout [merge_base_pipeline comparisons for Generic Metrics reports](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/61282) on production,
that is currently behind the `merge_base_pipeline_for_metrics_comparison`
` feature flag.

<!-- Short description of what the feature is about and link to relevant other issues. -->

## Owners

- Team: ~"group::testing" 
- Most appropriate slack channel to reach out to: `#g_testing`
- Best individual to reach out to: @drewcimino
- PM: @jheimbuck_gl 

## Stakeholders

<!--
Are there any other stages or teams involved that need to be kept in the loop?

- Name of a PM
- The Support Team
- The Delivery Team
-->

## The Rollout Plan

- Partial Rollout on GitLab.com with testing groups
- Global rollout on GitLab.com for 24 hours, with active monitoring by ~"group::testing" 
- Remove flag as soon as it's ready

<!-- Which dashboards from https://dashboards.gitlab.net are most relevant? Sentry errors reports can also be useful to review -->

## Testing Groups/Projects/Users

<!-- If applicable, any groups/projects that are happy to have this feature turned on early. Some organizations may wish to test big changes they are interested in with a small subset of users ahead of time for example. -->

- [x] https://gitlab.com/drewcimino/generic-rails-project/-/merge_requests/1

## Expectations

### What are we expecting to happen?

We're expecting reduced noise overall, due to changes already merged into master (since the last rebase of the source branch) not being interpreted as part of the merge request.

### What might happen if this goes wrong?

Data will not render correctly, but nothing will be lost.

### What can we monitor to detect problems with this?

We'll look at metrics report diffs in merge requests on gitlab.com. Also for errors in sentry from the MergeRequestDiffWidgetEntity.

**Update** I'll be keeping an eye on `MergeRequestsController#show` in [Grafana](https://dashboards.gitlab.net/d/web-rails-controller/web-rails-controller?orgId=1&var-PROMETHEUS_DS=Global&var-environment=gprd&var-stage=main&var-controller=Projects::MergeRequestsController&var-action=show) for alarm bells. Anything looks funky there, I'll start digging.

## Rollout Steps

### Rollout on non-production environments

- [x] Ensure that the feature MRs have been deployed to non-production environments.
    - [ ] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-your-feature>`
- [x] Enable the feature globally on non-production environments.
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set `merge_base_pipeline_for_metrics_comparison` true --dev`
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set `merge_base_pipeline_for_metrics_comparison` true --staging`
- [x] Verify that the feature works as expected. Posting the QA result in this issue is preferable.

### Preparation before production rollout

- [x] Ensure that the feature MRs have been deployed to both production and canary.
    - [ ] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-your-feature>`
- [x] Check if the feature flag change needs to be accompanied with a
  [change management issue](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/change-management/#feature-flags-and-the-change-management-process).
  Cross link the issue here if it does.
- [x] Ensure that you or a representative in development can be available for at least 2 hours after feature flag updates in production.
  If a different developer will be covering, or an exception is needed, please inform the oncall SRE by using the `@sre-oncall` Slack alias.
- [ ] Ensure that documentation has been updated ([More info](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/feature_flags.html#features-that-became-enabled-by-default)).
- [x] Announce on [the feature issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/61282) an estimated time this will be enabled on GitLab.com.
- [ ] If the feature flag in code has [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), enable it on GitLab.com for [testing groups/projects](#testing-groupsprojectsusers).
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set --<actor-type>=<actor> <feature-flag-name> true`
- [x] Verify that the feature works as expected. Posting the QA result in this issue is preferable.

### Global rollout on production

- [ ] [Incrementally roll out](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#process) the feature. If there is no risk that the feature affects usability or server loads, skip to the global rollout.
  - If the feature flag in code has [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), perform **actor-based** rollout.
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> <rollout-percentage> --actors`
  - If the feature flag in code does **NOT** have [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), perform time-based rollout (**random** rollout).
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> <rollout-percentage>`
- [x] Enable the feature globally on production environment.
  - [x] `/chatops run feature set merge_base_pipeline_for_metrics_comparison true`
  - [x] Done, 12:54 ET https://gitlab.slack.com/archives/C101F3796/p1621616021275000
- [x] Announce on [the feature issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/61282) that the feature has been globally enabled.
- [x] Cross-post chatops slack command to `#support_gitlab-com`.
  ([more guidance when this is necessary in the dev docs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#communicate-the-change)) and in your team channel
- [ ] Wait for [at least one day for the verification term](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release).

### (Optional) Release the feature with the feature flag

If you're still unsure whether the feature is [deemed stable](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release)
but want to release it in the current milestone, you can change the default state of the feature flag to be enabled.
To do so, follow these steps:

- [ ] Create a merge request with the following changes. Ask for review and merge it.
    - [ ] Set the `default_enabled` attribute in [the feature flag definition](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-flag-definition-and-validation) to `true`.
    - [ ] Create [a changelog entry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#changelog).
- [ ] Ensure that the above MR has been deployed to both production and canary.
      If the merge request was deployed before [the code cutoff](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/releases/#self-managed-releases-1),
      the feature can be officially announced in a release blog post.
    - [ ] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit>`
- [ ] Close [the feature issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/61282) to indicate the feature will be released in the current milestone.

**WARNING:** This approach has the downside that it makes it difficult for us to
[clean up](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up) the flag.
For example, on-premise users could disable the feature on their GitLab instance. But when you
remove the flag at some point, they suddenly see the feature as enabled and they can't roll it back
to the previous behavior. To avoid this potential breaking change, use this approach only for urgent
matters.

### Release the feature

After the feature has been [deemed stable](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release),
the [clean up](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up)
should be done as soon as possible to permanently enable the feature and reduce complexity in the
codebase.

<!-- The checklist here is to help stakeholders keep track of the feature flag status -->
- [x] Create a merge request to remove `merge_base_pipeline_for_metrics_comparison` feature flag. Ask for review and merge it.
    - [x] Remove all references to the feature flag from the codebase.
    - [x] Remove the YAML definitions for the feature from the repository.
    - [x] Create [a changelog entry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#changelog).
- [x] Ensure that the above MR has been deployed to both production and canary.
      If the merge request was deployed before [the code cutoff](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/releases/#self-managed-releases-1),
      the feature can be officially announced in a release blog post.
    - [ ] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit>`
- [x] Close [the feature issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/61282) to indicate the feature will be released in the current milestone.
- [x] Clean up the feature flag from all environments by running these chatops command in `#production` channel:
    - [x] `/chatops run feature delete <feature-flag-name> --dev`
    - [x] `/chatops run feature delete <feature-flag-name> --staging`
    - [x] `/chatops run feature delete <feature-flag-name>`
- [x] Close this rollout issue.

## Rollback Steps

- [ ] This feature can be disabled by running the following Chatops command:

```
/chatops run feature set merge_base_pipeline_for_metrics_comparison false
```

title: BE: Retrieve labels of a Jira issue on details page
description:
### Description

This is related to the other backend issue https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/333127 and also corresponds with the frontend issue https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/328787.

We get all the Jira Issue data in one request using the jira-ruby gem ([`jira_service.find_issue`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/8415ff28e38eeaea4d55ae79d9165da6cb257a07/ee/app/controllers/projects/integrations/jira/issues_controller.rb#L62-65)).

In this case, we want to be able to modify the labels and update the new labels in Jira, we have to do something like:
1. Make a request (or several having pagination) to Jira in order to pull the available labels. Caveat: Only available for Jira cloud, see https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/293021#note_551848967.
2. Populate the UI with the available labels to be selected by the user https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/328787.

![Screen_Shot_2021-05-12_at_17.15.00](/uploads/476a02b5788d1aa2fc107bfd35656815/Screen_Shot_2021-05-12_at_17.15.00.png)

title: Check feature category assignments for the Static Analysis group
description:
### Proposal 

We should audit our codebase to ensure the Sidekiq workers, controller actions, and API endpoints are assigned to the right [feature category](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_categorization/index.html#feature-categorization) in the Sec section.

This will make them showing up on the group's grafana dashboard and the apdex and error-rates of these actions will then also contribute to the error budget (https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-com/gl-infra/-/epics/437) for the group.

### Current categorizations

As of May 18, 2021, these are the current feature categories assigned to SAST:

```
./app/workers/concerns/security_scans_queue.rb:    feature_category :static_application_security_testing
./app/controllers/projects/security/configuration_controller.rb:      feature_category :static_application_security_testing
./ee/app/controllers/ee/projects/security/configuration_controller.rb:          feature_category :static_application_security_testing
./ee/app/controllers/ee/projects/merge_requests_controller.rb:        feature_category :static_application_security_testing, [:sast_reports]
./ee/app/controllers/projects/security/dashboard_controller.rb:      feature_category :static_application_security_testing
./ee/app/controllers/projects/security/sast_configuration_controller.rb:      feature_category :static_application_security_testing
```

And for Secret Detection:

```
ee/app/controllers/ee/projects/merge_requests_controller.rb:        feature_category :secret_detection, [:secret_detection_reports]
```

Current features categories(SAST) assigned to `sidekiq` jobs:

```
ee/app/workers/sync_security_reports_to_report_approval_rules_worker.rb: include SecurityScansQueue
ee/app/workers/store_security_scans_worker.rb: include SecurityScansQueue
ee/app/workers/security/store_scans_worker.rb: include SecurityScansQueue
ee/app/workers/scan_security_report_secrets_worker.rb: include SecurityScansQueue
ee/app/workers/store_security_reports_worker.rb: include SecurityScansQueue
```

title: Check feature category assignments for the Composition Analysis group.
description:
### Proposal 

We should audit our codebase to ensure the Sidekiq workers, controller actions, and API endpoints are assigned to the right [feature category](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_categorization/index.html#feature-categorization) in the Sec section.

This will make them showing up on the [group's grafana dashboard](https://dashboards.gitlab.net/d/stage-groups-composition_analysis/stage-groups-group-dashboard-secure-composition-analysis?orgId=1) and the apdex and error-rates of these actions will then also contribute to the error budget (https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-com/gl-infra/-/epics/437) for the group.

Example MR: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/60698

### Implementation Plan

1. Update the following controllers to ensure that all actions are assigned to the correct feature category:

   1. [`Projects::DependenciesController`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/35644c23da3/ee/app/controllers/projects/dependencies_controller.rb#L9-9)
   1. [`API::Dependencies`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/35644c23da3/ee/lib/api/dependencies.rb#L5-5)
   1. [`Projects::LicensesController`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/35644c23da3/ee/app/controllers/projects/licenses_controller.rb#L10-10)
   1. [`API::ManagedLicenses`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/35644c23da3/ee/lib/api/managed_licenses.rb#L7)

1. Ensure that there are no other security controllers that have an incorrectly configured [feature category](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_categorization/index.html#feature-categorization)
1. Update any secure Sidekiq workers to ensure they're assigned the correct [feature category](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_categorization/index.html#feature-categorization)
1. Update any other secure API endpoints to ensure they're assigned the correct [feature category](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_categorization/index.html#feature-categorization)

- [ ] Ensure that documentation has been updated ([More info](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/feature_flags.html#features-that-became-enabled-by-default)).
- [ ] Announce on [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) an estimated time this will be enabled on GitLab.com.
- [ ] If the feature flag in code has [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), enable it on GitLab.com for [testing groups/projects](#testing-groupsprojectsusers).
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set --<actor-type>=<actor> <feature-flag-name> true`
- [ ] Verify that the feature works as expected. Posting the QA result in this issue is preferable.

### Global rollout on production

- [ ] [Incrementally roll out](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#process) the feature. If there is no risk that the feature affects usability or server loads, skip to the global rollout.
  - If the feature flag in code has [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), perform **actor-based** rollout.
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> <rollout-percentage> --actors`
  - If the feature flag in code does **NOT** have [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), perform time-based rollout (**random** rollout).
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> <rollout-percentage>`
- [x] Enable the feature globally on production environment.
  - [ ] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> true`
- [ ] Announce on [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) that the feature has been globally enabled.
- [ ] Cross-post chatops slack command to `#support_gitlab-com`.
  ([more guidance when this is necessary in the dev docs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#communicate-the-change)) and in your team channel
- [ ] Wait for [at least one day for the verification term](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release).

### (Optional) Release the feature with the feature flag

If you're still unsure whether the feature is [deemed stable](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release)
but want to release it in the current milestone, you can change the default state of the feature flag to be enabled.
To do so, follow these steps:

- [ ] Create a merge request with the following changes. Ask for review and merge it.
    - [ ] Set the `default_enabled` attribute in [the feature flag definition](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-flag-definition-and-validation) to `true`.
    - [ ] Create [a changelog entry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#changelog).
- [ ] Ensure that the above MR has been deployed to both production and canary.
      If the merge request was deployed before [the code cutoff](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/releases/#self-managed-releases-1),
      the feature can be officially announced in a release blog post.
    - [ ] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit>`
- [ ] Close [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) to indicate the feature will be released in the current milestone.

**WARNING:** This approach has the downside that it makes it difficult for us to
[clean up](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up) the flag.
For example, on-premise users could disable the feature on their GitLab instance. But when you
remove the flag at some point, they suddenly see the feature as enabled and they can't roll it back
to the previous behavior. To avoid this potential breaking change, use this approach only for urgent
matters.

### Release the feature

After the feature has been [deemed stable](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release),
the [clean up](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up)
should be done as soon as possible to permanently enable the feature and reduce complexity in the
codebase.

<!-- The checklist here is to help stakeholders keep track of the feature flag status -->
- [ ] Create a merge request to remove `<feature-flag-name>` feature flag. Ask for review and merge it.
    - [ ] Remove all references to the feature flag from the codebase.
    - [ ] Remove the YAML definitions for the feature from the repository.
    - [ ] Create [a changelog entry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#changelog).
- [ ] Ensure that the above MR has been deployed to both production and canary.
      If the merge request was deployed before [the code cutoff](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/releases/#self-managed-releases-1),
      the feature can be officially announced in a release blog post.
    - [ ] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit>`
- [ ] Close [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) to indicate the feature will be released in the current milestone.
- [ ] Clean up the feature flag from all environments by running these chatops command in `#production` channel:
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature delete <feature-flag-name> --dev`
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature delete <feature-flag-name> --staging`
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature delete <feature-flag-name>`
- [ ] Close this rollout issue.

## Rollback Steps

- [ ] This feature can be disabled by running the following Chatops command:

```
/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> false
```

title: Group Level Access Tokens should be able to pull/push with git over http
description:
The generic implementation for Group level bot users works but [the fix for bot users to be able to use tokens for git operation over http](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/40635/diffs) is not generic and doesn't feature group level token validation. Please fix this too before release of  https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/214046

### Proposal

Group access tokens should be able to pull/push with git over http.

When attempting to use a resource access token to authenticate against git over http, add a check to see if the resource access token belongs to a user in either the project or an ancestor group; if yes, allow authentication.

This issue is an extension of https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/40635, which introduced the ability for *project* access tokens to authenticate over http.
