title: Extend KAS/AgentK to support fetching vulnerabilityreports.aquasecurity.github.io
description:
<!-- triage-serverless v3 PLEASE DO NOT REMOVE THIS SECTION -->
*This page may contain information related to upcoming products, features and functionality.
It is important to note that the information presented is for informational purposes only, so please do not rely on the information for purchasing or planning purposes.
Just like with all projects, the items mentioned on the page are subject to change or delay, and the development, release, and timing of any products, features, or functionality remain at the sole discretion of GitLab Inc.*
<!-- triage-serverless v3 PLEASE DO NOT REMOVE THIS SECTION -->
## Why are we doing this work

We want to allow customers to collect vulnerabilities from images in running Kubernetes clusters so they can understand their current security risk not only for images that are scanned as a part of CI Pipeline, but also for images that were deployed without using GitLab CI.

You can find more about our motivation to work on this issue [here](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/3410#problem-to-solve).

This issue is about extending `gitlab-agent` (GitLab Kubernetes Agent) project with new internal module to watch for vulnerabilities in the running cluster and create new vulnerability using internal API (introduced in #330715) based on found report.

## Relevant links
- [Epic](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/3410)
- [Design](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/219173)
- [Similar implementation](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/cluster-integration/gitlab-agent/-/merge_requests/211)
- [Retrieving vulnerability reports](https://github.com/aquasecurity/starboard/blob/main/pkg/apis/aquasecurity/v1alpha1/vulnerability_types.go#L87)

## Non-functional requirements
<!--
Add details for required items and delete others.
-->

- [x] Documentation:
  - Document new agent configuration options
- [x] Feature flag:
- [x] Performance:
- [x] Testing:
  - Test if you can get vulnerabilities found in the running cluster,
  - Test if found vulnerability in the running cluster triggers new Vulnerability creation,

## Implementation plan

**Note.** Take a look at https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/cluster-integration/gitlab-agent/-/merge_requests/211/ for inspiration

1. [x] ~backend Add new agent configuration options to [agentcfg.proto](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/cluster-integration/gitlab-agent/-/blob/34409ad04b6a76c68dc51038585a22c378725adf/pkg/agentcfg/agentcfg.proto#L94) and use `protoc-gen-go` to regenerate the protobuf go files.
   These are read from [config.yml](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/clusters/agent/repository.html#synchronize-manifest-projects) and should allow for the same configuration options as [the Cluster Image Scanning analyzer](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/application_security/cluster_image_scanning/#cicd-variables-for-cluster-image-scanning)

   ```yml
   cluster_image_scanning:
     namespaces:
     - production
     - staging
     resources:
     - nginx
     - knative
     containers:
     - nginx
     - knative
     kinds:
     - deployment
   ```

1. [x] ~documentation Document new agent configuration options in [repository.md](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/ca21fe980cc4b09915c9d0fccac88c45812abbd6/doc/user/clusters/agent/repository.md)
1. [x] ~backend Create a [new agent module](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/cluster-integration/gitlab-agent/-/tree/7c2da92b1d27b14efd483169c3943db341f96caf/internal/module) named `cluster_image_scanning`
1. [x] ~backend In the module's `worker.go`, create a new worker which will:
   1. [x] Get the [VulnerabilityReportList](https://github.com/aquasecurity/starboard/blob/main/pkg/apis/aquasecurity/v1alpha1/vulnerability_types.go#L87) which matches the configured labels and [watch it](https://kubernetes.io/docs/reference/using-api/api-concepts/#efficient-detection-of-changes) to detect when there are new vulnerability reports
   1. [x] From the initial list, create new vulnerabilities from the vulnerability reports
   1. [x] Whenever the watch detects new vulnerability reports, create new vulnerabilities from them
   1. [x] See [cluster image scanning](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/cluster-image-scanning/-/blob/7b1377f4861b43ef5a56416cf0815f71e3ff507f/starboard/client.go#L80) for reference example, without watching
1. [x] ~backend In the module's `module.go`, load the configuration and create new workers
1. [x] ~backend In the module's `factory.go`, create new instances of the module
1. [x] ~backend Add the factory to [`constructModules()`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/cluster-integration/gitlab-agent/-/blob/7c2da92b1d27b14efd483169c3943db341f96caf/cmd/agentk/agentkapp/app.go) in `cmd/agentk/agentkapp/app.go`
1. [x] ~backend Use [MockGen](https://github.com/golang/mock) to generate mocks and write tests for modules components

description:
## Why are we doing this work

We want to allow customers to collect vulnerabilities from images in running Kubernetes clusters so they can understand their current security risk not only for images that are scanned as a part of CI Pipeline, but also for images that were deployed without using GitLab CI.

epic.title: Cluster Image Scanning (Vulnerability Scans against Running Containers)

title: Extend Scheduled Scan Execution Policy with Cluster Image Scanning scan
description:
## Why are we doing this work

We want to allow customers to collect vulnerabilities from images in running Kubernetes clusters so they can understand their current security risk not only for images that are scanned as a part of CI Pipeline, but also for images that were deployed without using GitLab CI.

You can find more about our motivation to work on this issue [here](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/3410#problem-to-solve).

This issue is about extending Scheduled Scan Execution Policy to support Cluster Image Scanning scan. Customer will be able to schedule a security scan of running containers on selected time and select which namespace and resource names should be scanned. The `namespaces`, `resources`, `kinds`, and `containers` fields in policy configuration should be optional. When the user does not provide them, we should fetch all found vulnerabilities in the cluster:

```yml
scan_execution_policy:
  name: Run Cluster Image Scan
  description: This policy enforces container scans against a production cluster on a daily basis.
  enabled: true
  rules:
  - type: schedule
    clusters:
      production:
        namespaces:
        - production
        - staging
        resources:
        - nginx
        - knative
        containers:
        - nginx
        - knative
        kinds:
        - deployment
    cadence: 0 0 * * *
  actions:
  - scan: cluster_image_scanning
```

## Relevant links
- [Epic](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/3410)
- [Design](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/219173)


## Non-functional requirements
<!--
Add details for required items and delete others.
-->

- [ ] Documentation: add documentation to `doc/user/application_security/policies/index.md` with information how to configure policy to use this analyzer,
- [-] Feature flag: no feature flag is needed as this is something that users will optionally select by including the GitLab CI template
- [-] Performance:
- [ ] Testing:
  - Test if you can configure policy to ,
  - Test if vulnerabilities from security report from `cluster_image_scanning` analyzer are visible in database


## Implementation plan

- [ ] ~backend extend `ee/app/validators/json_schemas/security_orchestration_policy.json` with new action scan type `cluster_image_scan` and check if `namespaces`, `resources`, `kinds`, and `containers` fields are valid when provided (both are optional for this new scan type),
- [ ] ~backend extend `ee/lib/gitlab/ci/config/security_orchestration_policies/processor.rb` with logic to extend config when `cluster_image_scan` is provided in policy (you could create new service similar to Security::SecurityOrchestrationPolicies::OnDemandScanPipelineConfigurationService to prepare the job configuration),
- [ ] ~backend extend `process_action` method in `ee/app/services/security/security_orchestration_policies/rule_schedule_service.rb` to support new scan `cluster_image_scan` and start new pipeline with `Cluster Image Scan` job only (create new service to manage that, like `DastOnDemandScans::CreateService`),
- [ ] ~backend create new service `Security::SecurityOrchestrationPolicies::CreatePipelineService` that will be responsible for starting new pipeline with selected security scan. In this new service we will create and start new pipeline:
```ruby
Ci::CreatePipelineService
  .new(project, current_user, ref: branch)
  .execute(:security_orchestration_policy, content: ci_yaml)
```
- [x] ~backend extend `self.sources` method in `app/models/concerns/enums/ci/pipeline.rb` with new value: `security_orchestration_policy: 14`, add `security_orchestration_policy` to slice arguments in `self.dangling_sources` method,
- [x] ~backend extend `dangling_build?` method in `lib/gitlab/ci/pipeline/chain/command.rb` with `security_orchestration_policy`,
- [ ] ~backend remember to send values of `namespaces` and `resources` fields to job configuration and make sure that analyzer receives and uses these values to properly fetch vulnerabilities from the cluster whenever we are configuring   `cluster_image_scan` job

title: Add new GitLab CI template for Cluster Image Scanning
description:
## Why are we doing this work

We want to allow customers to collect vulnerabilities from images in running Kubernetes clusters so they can understand their current security risk not only for images that are scanned as a part of CI Pipeline, but also for images that were deployed without using GitLab CI.

You can find more about our motivation to work on this issue [here](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/3410#problem-to-solve).

This issue is about creating new Security template in `lib/gitlab/ci/templates/Security/` folder that will use analyzer to get vulnerabilities from connected Kubernetes cluster. You can see a Proof of Concept of this template here: https://gitlab.com/mparuszewski/live-container-scanning-test.

## Relevant links
- [Epic](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/3410)
- [Design](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/219173)
- [Proof of concept](https://gitlab.com/mparuszewski/live-container-scanning-test)


## Non-functional requirements
<!--
Add details for required items and delete others.
-->

- [x] Documentation: new template should be documented in https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/application_security/#security-scanning-tools
- [-] Feature flag: no feature flag is needed as this is something that users will optionally select by including the GitLab CI template
- [-] Performance:
- [x] Testing:
  - Test if you can fetch vulnerabilities from kubernetes cluster and prepare JSON report with them in GitLab format,


## Implementation plan

- [x] ~backend create new template in `lib/gitlab/ci/templates/Security/` folder, so customers can include it to fetch vulnerabilities from connected clusters,
- [x] ~backend remember to add `CLUSTER_IMAGE_DISABLED` variable, so user can easily disable this,
- [x] ~documentation add initial documentation to https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/application_security/#security-scanning-tools

title: Implement new analyzer to fetch vulnerabilities from running containers
description:
## Why are we doing this work

We want to allow customers to collect vulnerabilities from images in running Kubernetes clusters so they can understand their current security risk not only for images that are scanned as a part of CI Pipeline, but also for images that were deployed without using GitLab CI.

You can find more about our motivation to work on this issue [here](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/3410#problem-to-solve).

This issue is about creating new analyzer (https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/cluster-image-scanning) in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/ group to fetch vulnerabilities from running cluster. You can see a Proof of Concept of this analyzer here: https://gitlab.com/mparuszewski/live-container-scanning.

In current iteration the analyzer will connect with `kubectl` to the cluster (with `KUBECONFIG` environment variable) and will be able to get all vulnerabilities for selected namespaces and resource names. Ie. You should be able to configure the analyzer to fetch vulnerabilities in namespaces that are matching `production-*` wildcard and with resource names that are matching `nginx-*` wildcard (vulnerabilities for all ReplicaSets with name starting with `nginx-` prefix in namespaces with name starting with `production-` prefix). After vulnerability reports are fetched from Kubernetes cluster, analyzer has to parse and convert found vulnerabilities to format supported in GitLab (see https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/security-report-schemas).

Value for `KUBECONFIG` variable will be provided from GitLab CI as predefined variable when Project is connected to Kubernetes cluster or as a variable provided manually by user in `Project->Settings->CI Variables`.

There is no preference about the technology used in this analyzer (either Go or Ruby will work for us), however ideally (since we want to extend `kas` in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/330716, which is written in Go) we want to go with Go language to reuse this logic later in Kubernetes Agent.

## Relevant links
- [Epic](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/3410)
- [Design](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/219173)
- [Proof of concept](https://gitlab.com/mparuszewski/live-container-scanning)


## Non-functional requirements
<!--
Add details for required items and delete others.
-->

- [ ] Documentation: should be added to document usage of new analyzer
- [-] Feature flag: no feature flag is needed as this is something that users will optionally select by including the GitLab CI template
- [-] Performance:
- [ ] Testing:
  - Test if you can fetch vulnerabilities from kubernetes cluster and prepare JSON report with them in GitLab format,


## Implementation plan

1. ~backend create new project in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers and prepare analyzer that will fetch vulnerabilities from Kubernetes cluster for credentials provided in `KUBECONFIG` environment variable
2. ~documentation add README and documentation to document usage of new analyzer,

title: High number of running Jobs cause slowness on pipeline page
description:
### Summary

If a pipeline is triggered with a huge number of Jobs (tested this with a 1000), the pipeline page for the project becomes inaccessible until all jobs have finished.

The side effect of the a huge `gitlab-ci` file is also that it take several minutes before the pipeline is created.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Create a project with this [gitlab-ci.yml](/uploads/177f3d79b19403794c5897a7d181438a/gitlab-ci.yml) file.
2. Run the pipeline.

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

The jobs run but the pipline page is completely inaccessible.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

The jobs to run without affecting the pipeline page.

### Possible fixes

related ticket: https://gitlab.zendesk.com/agent/tickets/209667

Preload users for [`Ci::Build#detailed_status`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/39d77d5665ef91719360ff586520953769af1262/app/models/ci/build.rb#L416-420), `tags and runners` for [`Ci::Build#stuck?`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/39d77d5665ef91719360ff586520953769af1262/app/models/ci/build.rb#L768-770). More details about the queries: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/330707#note_599344210


### Availability & Testing

<!-- This section needs to be retained and filled in during the workflow planning breakdown phase of this feature proposal, if not earlier.

What risks does this change pose to our availability? How might it affect the quality of the product? What additional test coverage or changes to tests will be needed? Will it require cross-browser testing?

Please list the test areas (unit, integration and end-to-end) that needs to be added or updated to ensure that this feature will work as intended. Please use the list below as guidance.
* Unit test changes
* Integration test changes
* End-to-end test change

See the test engineering planning process and reach out to your counterpart Software Engineer in Test for assistance: https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/quality/test-engineering/#test-planning -->

* Unit test changes: requires unit tests for N+1 queries.
* Integration test changes: Can we mock this many jobs in a pipeline in a feature test? Is it reasonable?
* End-to-end test change: perhaps this is not a good option for E2E test but rather a load test scenario.

See the test engineering planning process and reach out to your counterpart Software Engineer in Test for assistance: https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/quality/test-engineering/#test-planning

title: Potential: Update BuildQueueWorker to utilize new Sidekiq readonly database replicas
description:
With the ability to [Allow Sidekiq jobs to use readonly database replicas](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/322452) in place, the next step will be to enable this capability for this worker.

## Proposal

Use `data_consistency :sticky` because it's the best trade-off. A data consistency `delayed` could cause the job to be rescheduled if the replica hasn't caught up, but the worker is set to run with `urgency :high` so we want to avoid that. A `sticky` mode still allows us to use replica as much as possible.

title: Rename remaining classes that operate on integrations to use the word "integration" instead of "service"
description:
See https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/330670#note_575341780 for a list of classes to rename (although there may be more). Note that `ServiceHook` has its own separate issue https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/335882.

As part of https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/2504 we have started the process of renaming integration classes (https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/201848 and https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/201855).

This issue is to:

1. Rename all other classes that operate on integrations to use the word _integration_ instead of _service_ in its name. 
1. Where possible these classes should be namespaced in `Integrations::` also.
1. Update the regexes needed to support these files in `tooling/danger/project_helper.rb` https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/74330

title: Update translations levels (June 2021)
description:
## Introduction

With the implementation of the feature to show the [translation coverage](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/328430) in the language selection dropdown, the translation levels need to be updated on a monthly cadence. 

## Proposal

Once the monthly merge of the new translations is complete, update the translation levels [data](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/gitlab/i18n.rb#L40) from Crowdin.

## Documentation

* https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/i18n/merging_translations.html#manually-update-the-translation-levels

#### ToDo
* [x] Complete the [regular monthly merge](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/3571) of translations from Crowdin. https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/329887
* [x] Get the translation levels (% approved words) from [Crowdin](https://crowdin.com/project/gitlab-ee/settings#translations).
* [x] Create an MR to update the translation levels [data](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/gitlab/i18n.rb#L40).
* [x] Associate that MR to this issue.
* [x] Complete the MR.
* [x] When done, clone this issue for the next milestone.

title: Quickly copy code blocks in the Content Editor
description:
## Problem to solve

Code blocks (content fenced by ```) in Markdown are often used to share multiple lines of code in documentation. In these scenarios, it's expected that someone reading the content might want to copy that code to their clipboard for use in their IDE. This currently requires the viewer to highlight the text. Spacing can be important so if you're not precise with your selection, the code copied to your clipboard may not work.

There's got to be a better way!

![c9Ups](/uploads/2bf010364970008c88a6ae6e1d5467b1/c9Ups.gif)

## Proposal

Extend the functionality of rendered code blocks in the Content Editor to include a copy button on every one. This button should copy the entire content of the code block to the local clipboard. 

## Details

## Open questions

- In order to reduce visual clutter, maybe this button only appears when the cursor is hovering over a code block? Will this make it too hard to discover?

epic.title: Make code blocks more useful in the Content Editor
